data.title: Can't install `code-oss` in PATH
data.body:
I was trying to set-up Code in order to submit a PR for #33106, for which I need to have the `code-oss` command installed, but after running the command for installing it I get a message saying "This command is not available".

Maybe it's unrelated, but if I run `code --help` from `Code - OSS`'s terminal I get a "Cannot read property 'indexOf' of undefined", it works when executed in a regular terminal.

Did I miss something?

Steps to Reproduce:

1. git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode
2. cd vscode
3. ./scripts/npm.sh install
4. npm run watch
5. ./scripts/code.sh
6. Execute the `Install code-oss` command

- VSCode Version: code-oss-dev 1.17.0 (Commit unknown, Date unknown)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 17.0.0
- Extensions: none

data.title: Extension @sort:rating is out of order
data.body:
When searching for an extension, and sorting by rating, the sort displays out of order. As you can see there are ones with a rating followed by ones without a rating followed by more with a rating.

Also, they are out of order, where there are some `4.5`'s before `5`'s (however this part of the order could be based on the total number of ratings as well).

![extension-sorting](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1571806/30186265-69b802c4-93ea-11e7-97ca-b1753aada134.png)

data.title: Allow local masking of selected text
data.body:
As bad a practice as it is, there are often times where passwords or relatively sensitive information need to be kept in plain text documents, config files, or the like. The ability to mask the selected text would allow for at least some sort of local protection to prevent this sort of information from being seen by others that happen to be looking at your screen or passing by.

Currently, the closest way I can think of to perform something like this is to move the sensitive information to a new, indented line, and fold that particular block, but this is a little on the cumbersome side, and depending on the type of file, might cause issues with the functionality by breaking it to a new line.

data.title: Option to disable thread exit logging in launch.json
data.body:
Desired Behavior:

I'd like the ability to disable thread exit messages in the Debug Console. Options already exist for other types of messages such as module loads (under logging.moduleLoad), so this would simply be another one added to the list.

1. Launch a C++ program under the debugger
2. Notice "The thread #### has exited with code 0 (0x0)" messages in the Debug Console

data.title: Intellisense broken for index.js ommited ES6 imports
data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.15.1 - OS Version: Mac OSX Sierra 10.12.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a basic project structure as follows, ``` Sample ├── components │   ├── index.js │   └── module.js ├── jsconfig.json └── test.js ``` Included `jsconfig.json` is, ```json { "compilerOptions": { "module": "es6" } } ``` 2. Export some object from `module.js` as default, ```js const Module = { PROP: 'prop' } export default Module; ``` 3. In component `index.js`, export `Module`, ```js export {default as Module} from './module.js'; ``` 4. In `test.js` attempt to import `Module`, and intellisense only works if index included in path. ```js import { Module } from './components'; // No intellisense here Module.PROP ``` 5. Screen shots I'm assuming this may be related to the fact that intellisense could also interpret `./component` to be a file without an extension, ex. `./component.js` ### Context We're building a large application with many subdirectories of components. Gives way to better organizing and cleaning up import syntax within files. Reproduces without extensions: **Yes**

data.title: No Visible Indicator of New Version of VS Code with Hidden Activity Bar.
data.body:
With the recent change that removes the popup window when a new update is indicated, if you have the activity bar hidden then there's no way to know there's a new update.

```JSON
"workbench.activityBar.visible": false
```

Also not sure if there is a command to update VS Code through the command palette. There is `Extensions: Check for Updates` but I don't think that includes VS Code.

data.title: Clarify documentation on "engines" field in package.json
data.body:
The [docs](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/extension-manifest) say for `engines`:
> An object containing at least the vscode key matching the versions of VS Code that the extension is compatible with. Cannot be *. For example: ^0.10.5 indicates compatibility with a minimum VS Code version of 0.10.5.

It's not clear to me what happens when you publish an update with an engines constraint that targets the next Code version (currently Insiders). That is, will this update be invisible for regular non-insider users and only the insider users will see it? The other scenario would be that non-insider users would see an update that they can't install.

Also, is it possible to release updates on two different streams, e.g. let's say 1.2.3 is the current non-insiders release to which I can publish updates like 1.2.4 while at the same time releasing a 1.3.0 version targeting insiders, again with updates for it, like 1.3.1.

I assume it all just works out but documenting that somewhere would help.

data.title: Problem debugging extensions after upgrading to 1.16.0
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0 (just released)
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new extension with `yo code` accepting all the defaults (name it anything you like).
2. Press F5 to launch your new extension into the debugger.
3. After 10 seconds, the debugger fails to connect.  A message appears at the top of the parent VSCode instance:

> Error: Ensure Node was launched with --inspect. Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after 10000 ms - (reason: Response from the target seems invalid: [ {

I tried upgrading NodeJS to v8.4.0, but no luck.  `package.json` and `.vscode/launch.json` just have the standard output from `yo code` in them.

data.title: Scrolling up in terminal doesn't pin the scroll position
data.body:
Reported in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11542#issuecomment-327740189
Upstream issue: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/953

Repro:

- Press enter a bunch of times
- Run `while true; do echo "hi"; sleep 1; done`
- Scroll up
- Notice that instead of the viewport staying on that text, it's continually scrolling down 1 row when "hi" is added to the bottom.

data.title: electron@1.7.7
CodeLensContribution causes scrolling jump when rift view is centered in editor.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: code-oss-dev 1.17.0 (9a06ffca7835df3677e7219dd983382baeaa0ea7, Date unknown)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.7.0
gitlens|eam|4.4.3
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
git-tree-compare|let|1.1.0
Go|luk|0.6.65
node-debug2|ms-|1.14.5
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.2.1
sourcegraph|sou|1.0.9
vim|vsc|0.10.0
---

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have an extension installed that registers a CodeLensProvider (e.g. gitlens)
2. Open VS Code to a file (e.g. codelensController.ts) and scroll (make sure you have scrolled a non-zero amount) to a symbol in the middle of the file.
4. Right click on a symbol and "find references".
5. Adjust your window size and scroll position so the references peek view is in the middle of the screen and takes up most of the vertical height.
6. Close and reopen vscode (or refresh it if running `./scripts/code.sh`) 
7. Immediately right click on the same symbol and find references. (i.e. before code lens has resolved).

After the references returns, you will see the scroll position jump because CodeLensContribution tries to restore the center range:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/9a06ffca7835df3677e7219dd983382baeaa0ea7/src/vs/editor/contrib/codelens/browser/codelensController.ts#L256-L258

The problem is that the references rift view is actually in the center of the viewport, so the "center" line that CodeLensProvider saves to restore is actually the line after the rift view. Centering that line causes the rift view to scroll up off the screen (unexpected).



![screen recording 2017-09-07 at 11 17 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/754768/30178566-3f03e268-93be-11e7-8d73-b41047f7568e.gif)

The following diff is helpful for debugging
```diff
diff --git a/src/vs/editor/contrib/codelens/browser/codelensController.ts b/src/vs/editor/contrib/codelens/browser/codelensController.ts
index ac409e2a56..2c06adac0b 100644
--- a/src/vs/editor/contrib/codelens/browser/codelensController.ts
+++ b/src/vs/editor/contrib/codelens/browser/codelensController.ts
@@ -254,7 +254,10 @@ export class CodeLensContribution implements editorCommon.IEditorContribution {
 			});
 		});
 		if (shouldRestoreCenteredRange) {
+			console.warn('revealRangeInCenter', centeredRange);
 			this._editor.revealRangeInCenter(centeredRange, editorCommon.ScrollType.Immediate);
+		} else {
+			console.log('not revealing range');
 		}
 	}
 

```

The ideal solution would be to adjust the scroll position by exactly the amount of content that was added by the code lenses.

data.title: Language Server are not run in debug mode when debugging
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:12:42.401Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.2.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
prettier-vscode|esb|0.23.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.2.1
vetur|oct|0.9.5
vim|vsc|0.10.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

1. Clone https://github.com/vuejs/vetur
2. Run `yarn` at `/`, `/server`, `/client`
3. Run `yarn watch` at `/server`
4. Debug using the compound debug target, `all`. Does not activate extension correctly. Error says 

    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/30177543-0559bf68-93bb-11e7-8d28-54d3bcb038e9.png). Vue Language Server is not started at all.

5. Debug using the `client` target only. Launches VSCode and Vue Language Server correctly. However, the option being used is `run` instead of `debug` for `ServerOptions`: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/b0b7ebd59f935338f3023f747ca8e75e91f15018/client/src/main.ts#L69

    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4033249/30177682-6e7a11aa-93bb-11e7-86c7-325cf44fcce9.png)
    In last version, `debugServerModule` would be run when debugging. Now it's running `serverModule` when debugging.

@weinand @dbaeumer

data.title: New install of VSC x64 on Windows hogs CPU renders machine unresponsive
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012 R2 (2GB Ram - It's a VM)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VSC x64 or x32
2. Open Task Manager
3. Launch
4. Watch machine grind to a halt

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99895/30164748-71d3e2a8-93d5-11e7-8dd2-13d003557c28.png)

Image shows the issue.  The issue happens with or without the folder opened in VSC (it was an issue directly from first launch).

Can't even close VSC with X or File->Exit, have to end task.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
No extensions were installed, it was a clean install.  
Running with code --disable-extensions shows the same issue.

I uninstalled and installed the 32 bit version, and I get exactly the same problem.

Have now uninstalled completely.
